document.docTitle: Macrohydnobius montanus Peck & Cook 2009, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Review of the Sogdini of North and Central America (Coleoptera: Leiodidae: Leiodinae) with descriptions of fourteen new species and three new genera

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 132–138.
Macrohydnobius montanus .
132. Right antenna, dorsal view. 133. Male mandibles, dorsal view. 134. Female mandibles, dorsal view. 135. Male right protibia. 136. Aedeagus, dorsal view. 137. Female sternite 8, ventral view. 138. Female coxites and styli, ventral view. Scale bar = 0.3 mm (Fig. 138), 0.5 mm (Figs. 136, 137), 0.75 mm (Fig. 132), 1.0 mm (Figs. 133 – 135).

FIGURE 139. Known western North American localities of
Macrohydnobius montanus
(black dots).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution. The species occurs in northwestern North America ( Fig. 139 ). We have seen specimens from
Canada :
the provinces of Alberta and British Columbia ;
USA :
the states of California , Idaho , Montana , Nevada , and Oregon .

Field notes and habitats. Adults have been collected in mixed forests of spruce-alder, or spruce-fir-aspen or lodgepole pine, and most commonly in flight interecept traps or on snow, and a few at uv light traps and in pitfall traps or malaise traps.
Seasonality. Adults have been collected in all months except March and April, but usually in low numbers, with larger numbers in August (30), September (12), and December (8).
Etymology. Named with reference to the western mountain habitat of this species.
